question: Take a left, no, I mean a right. Okay, stop for a second. We're here. Where the hell are you?
answer: Back here. At the end of the block. You got the cash?

question: You got the shit?
answer: Yeah, but you got to come the rest of the way on foot. Leave your car and walk over here.

question: Let me see it.
answer: Let me see it.

question: Where is it?
answer: I can't carry it in my pocket, man. And I can't go get it for you cause you might be a cop. You gonna have to pick it up yourself. Don't worry. It's just round the corner. Halfway down that block, you can't miss it. Top step of the front stairs, there's a loose stone. Go on, I ain't shitting you.

question: I got a great deal on it. They couldn't give this place away. Just dead meat stanking up their books for twenty years. The last owner on the lease before the bank was back in '79. Some dude named Jimmy Bones. Empty ever since.
answer: Jimmy Bones?

question: Yeah, you heard of him?
answer: You haven't?

question: Not that I remember.
answer: He was a local legend back in the '70's. There was a song, Stagolee kinda deal

question: Look around, this place is a dump! Naw, it'd have to work to be a dump.
answer: You gotta use your imagination.

question: "This is Patrick..." "...And this is Patrick on crack." Imagination, my butt. Even the space cowboy can't...
answer: Why don't y'all check out the rest? I'm going downstairs and see if I can get the furnace fired up. Warm this place up, you'll see. It has serious potential.

question: Potential toxic dump site.
answer: Are you nuts?

question: The man said just to use my imagination. Let's see...yeah, I get it. Potential. I can see it now. The first major urban theme park. Village Ghetto land. Kinda like Legoland, but made entirely from broken glass, hypodermic needles and crack vials. Totally E-ticket.
answer: Keep smokin', fool. What did you say?

question: I didn't say nothing.
answer: You didn't hear that? "Take him... " Something. "Bury him" or...

question: Hey, watcha doing with that dog?
answer: He yours, sir?

question: Hell no!
answer: Then what do you care?

question: Take my advice. And shoot that dog. Or let me.
answer: Alright. Yes sir. Anything you say.

question: Some holes can't be filled. Some hungers can't be satisfied.
answer: And some people need their medication tweaked.

question: I'm not joking boy. Don't feed it. It'll only make it hungrier.
answer: Need any help with those bags, Ma'am?

question: Say Eddie.
answer: Goddamnit! How many times I told you --

question: We got a gift for you, Eddie. Fresh new
answer: That you stole off those white boys was down here last night? Are you crazy? Everybody from hell to breakfast heard that screamin' on Blackstone last night!

question: But --
answer: How many times I told you, no psycho shit. There gonna be psycho shit, I'm the one that does it.

question: How many times I told you, no psycho shit. There gonna be psycho shit, I'm the one that does it.
answer: We didn't do nothing, Eddie.

question: You gon tell me you didn't ginsu those punks and steal their ride?
answer: That's all we did, steal their ride.

question: Hold up S-G. Give him a toot.
answer: 'Sup Jimmy B. Shotgun. Get back on the curb! Now!

question: Go easy on Jay Bird. I can remember when we was his age...
answer: It's all arranged for tonight. Eddie Mack's gonna be there. And Offisa Korruptsky, too.

question: They get about twelve and a half minutes. Tops.
answer: Trust me, Jimmy, there's big money behind this. Not just big. BIG. Like big business big. Big corporation big. Big government big. Our little acre alone'll net hundreds a thousands. Nothing but net.

question: Nothing but net? Could be a swish. Or a muthafucking air ball.
answer: One simple word, three little letters. Yes. That's all it's gonna take and we could move out of this dump, get the real deal. Big houses, legit business...

question: That's your dream, Homes. Not mine. I don't want to leave this street. Ever. The status quo is totally cool with me.
answer: Maybe I oughtta get there a little early. For good luck.

question: Don't need luck tonight. I'm just letting 'em have their say before I say no.
answer: Let me see your hand.

question: All that shinin' and "reader and adviser" mess. That was your mama's bag. I don't know about the readin' but you both can sure 'nuff advise.
answer: My mama's bag and my granma's bag, and a long line of mamas before her.

question: Sounds like mama needs a brand new bag.
answer: Such fine hands. You shoulda been a musician. You got the fingers. Left hand's the past. Your right's the present. And the future. But it's not written in stone. It's written in flesh and blood. And flesh and blood will change. See? There's something here, a new line, right across your life line.

question: Must be my clothes line. No? How bout my phone line?
answer: No baby. I'm serious. Cancel that meeting. I got more fruit that needs checking. Come home with me now.

question: Wait here. And don't touch my fucking sandwich. Not your style. Is it Eddie? Killing off your customers?
answer: I ain't killed nobody. Shall I rack 'em? Play a game, Lupe?

question: No time for eightball. I got your tip. Confiscated their whole stash. Fair enough for the shit. But I think a little bonus is due for knocking out the competition.
answer: You was just doing your job.

question: You wouldn't know a mule if it bit you in the ass. And personally, I don't need a mule. I got a Lexus. And nobody gave it to me -- What the hell do you want?
answer: Just a visit with my old pal, Jay-bird.

question: Don't call me that.
answer: You certainly traded up. ...the trophy wife. Nice lookin'.

question: Keep your hands to yourself, willya?
answer: I been watching you. You done good. Invested wisely. Respectable businessman now. Just like you always wanted.

question: And you? Still a pig. Just a much fatter one.
answer: No reason to get nasty. Yeah, I've stayed in the organization. But then again I never got the percentage you did.

question: Or you didn't know what to do with it.
answer: Maybe so. Maybe so. But that ain't why I came to see you. You sold the building.

question: What building?
answer: Don't shit a shitter. Our building. What did you call it? His 'tomb'? We had an agreement. You were supposed to sit on it. Not sell it --

question: I didn't sell it.
answer: Well, somebody bought it. That's what I heard.

question: Claire? Could you come in here. Did we sell any properties on... Blackstone recently? To who? No, of course not. Good work. Thanks a lot. You're right. One of my associates sold the building last month.
answer: That's a Bozo no-no. Jay-bird.

question: Look, even if anyone found anything there, it's twenty years ago. They could never connect it to us.
answer: You better hope not. Cause it's like they say, four can keep a secret, if three are dead. Nice rack. How old is --

question: That's it. Get out. Now!
answer: Hey, that's...

question: That's what?
answer: That's some terrible shit.

question: Clean your mouth, or I will. Those boys had no business messing down there. Go places you're not meant to be -- that's what you get.
answer: But that's your old hood, Pops.

question: Careful. That's bad luck.
answer: That place is already bad luck.

question: Why?
answer: No. It goes way back. Or so my Momma says.

question: What else does she say?
answer: Nothing. You'd think she was crazy. And she is a lot of things, not all of them nice, but crazy Momma's not.

question: Way I figure, everything our parents tell us is part true and part total B.S. And our whole job is figuring out for ourselves which is which.
answer: My momma says every house is two houses. Every street, two streets. There's a whole city, a whole world, kinda beside, on top, just below this one. The city of the dead.

question: Like right now, there's actually like hordes of dead people shambling around us? Fingers rotting off?
answer: Maybe. But there's an invisible wall, a fabric that kinda keeps things separate.

question: Lucky thing.
answer: Yeah. But when something bad happens, something really bad -- the wall breaks. The fabric tears.

question: The dead get out?
answer: Or the living fall in. Who knows.

question: And you believe her?
answer: If I did, I wouldn't come within fifty yards of your door.

question: Tia? Patrick? That you? Shit.
answer: Spooked?

question: No. Well, yeah. Maybe just a little.
answer: Yeah, there is a strange vibe here.

question: Where's the others?
answer: Maurice left. Tia's taking a bath. ...we just been in the damn suburbs too long.

question: We're all tired. Everybody makes mistakes. Tomorrow in the daylight, everything's gonna look different. I thought you were bringing the Colonel?
answer: The Gangster of Love don't eat no fried chicken.

question: Why not? He eats everything else.
answer: Just what army do you think the Colonel was in? Everybody knows the whole chicken distribution network is owned by the Klan. "Special recipe". I'm telling you. There's something in the batter. Say it makes a black man sterile. Word. I saw it on Sixty Minutes.

question: Maurice, even if it was true, what are you worried about? Last time I checked, you weren't black. I'm not sure what the hell you are. But I know you aren't a black man.
answer: I am the future. I am all colors. All races. All creeds. I am the melting pot. I am the tossed salad. I am post racial.

question: Welcome, brother. Welcome, sisters. Make yourselves comfortable around the circle. We'll begin in a minute. Aren't you going to join us?
answer: I have to finish this for class.

question: You got a vision, girl. Just like I got. Just like my momma had. And the good Lord didn't give you that vision just for painting pretty pictures. That's just wasted time.
answer: You mean as opposed to your life? I'm sorry, Momma. Maybe next time.

question: I don't want you meeting around that house. You stay away from those kids. And away from that dog.
answer: They seemed alright. Bring a little life to that old building.

question: Nothing but a wide world o' pain locked in there.
answer: Have you ever been inside?

question: Maybe once upon a time. But that was long ago. Back before... before it became what it is.
answer: And what's that?

question: Hello. Who're you?
answer: Boys and girls, Moms and Dads. Children of all ages, I'd like you to meet... Jimmy Bones.

question: What the hell you talking about?
answer: "This is the story of Jimmy Bones/Black as night and hard as stones/Gold plated deuce, like the King of Siam/Got his switchblade loose, and a diamond on his hand..." There's the switchblade and there's the diamond. Don't know where the deuce is parked.

question: You think that's really him?
answer: Damn. It's so...fresh.

question: Boy, put that thing down. You can't take that. Might be evidence.
answer: Evidence of what?

question: Somehow I don't think he stabbed himself in the chest, then buried himself too.
answer: Get your damn dog, girl! Shit! Damn dog. We gonna have to do something about you.

question: She doesn't want me here. With you. In this house.
answer: Believe me, my old man'd rupture his spleen if he knew we was down here. All he talks about is the medal he deserves for building us a life as far from this 'hood as possible.

question: He probably thinks he's saving you from something. I'm sure that's what my mother thinks.
answer: I'm sure I can make your mother like me. But then do I gotta worry 'bout your father?

question: Where are we going? You know I hate surprises.
answer: A little business move I made. On my own. I think you're gonna approve.

question: What are we doing down here?
answer: Like you always said, Pop, look for the undervalued. I bet you didn't even know your bank owned the place. I did it through a broker so you wouldn't know it was me. I couldn't wait to see your face when I fixed it up.

question: Is this some kind of sick joke? Listen to me, boy. I didn't work all my life to get out of this neighborhood for you to move right back in!
answer: I thought you'd be psyched. Just trying to do what you did. Take nothing and make something out of it.

question: No one'll ever come here. Shut it down. Don't worry, the bank'll buy it back. I'll take care of it.
answer: You'll take care of it? Not this time. No way. I bought it fair and square. And we open tonight.

question: Besides, there's more money to be made in the gin than the juice. What do anybody want with numbers anyway?
answer: What else? Money.

question: It ain't the money - it's the high. The big fat floating 'what if?' And it's way more profitable. Nobody ever wins. So you never have to pay out.
answer: But a two dollar bet is cheaper than a twenty-dollar bag.

question: Yeah, but I ain't talking horse. I'm talking about a five-dollar kick in the head that's a quick ticket to heaven. And the fools keep coming back for more.
answer: Those 'fools' are my people.

question: Ain't no big thang. It's just a po' man's free base. Here, check it out.
answer: I ain't interested. And if you gonna sell it, don't sell it round here.

question: Just try it.
answer: I said, no thanks.

question: Just try it, Jimmy. That's all...
answer: You heard the man. Try it.

question: Ain't worth it, Blood. Just drop it. And kick it here.
answer: Tell her to stop screaming. I said stop that bitch screaming or I'll spread her like butter. Get his razor. I ain't gonna be the only one with this nigger's blood on my hands. Take the gloves off. Everybody leaves a print. We hang out together. Or we hang separately. Cut him. And cut him good.

question: What it is? What it will be, muthafucka.
answer: Now you.

question: ...I've seen things. In there. Last night. You did too. Don't tell me you didn't. You were crying like a baby.
answer: You said the vision, the images. They're just that. Just pictures. They can't hurt you. That's what you always said.

question: I lied.
answer: All the more reason I should be here.

question: Please. It's for your own good.
answer: You said bad things hurt places. So maybe good things heal them. Good things are happening here. Maybe for the first time ever. And maybe that's all it takes.

question: It's alright, baby.
answer: Who was he, Momma? He tried to kill us.

question: If he was trying to kill you, you'd be dead.
answer: Who? Who is he? What is he?

question: Free at last, free at last.
answer: It wasn't my fault. I didn't know what they'd planned.

question: Shush. It don't matter now.
answer: No. Really, Jimmy. Remember, man. It's me. I was on your side. Don't you remember?

question: Take a look at what I remember, brother...
answer: I had no choice, Jimmy. What else could I do?

question: Did you do it?
answer: Sure, son. I went down there and torched the place myself.

question: You could have had it done. You didn't want us there.
answer: I wouldn't have risked killing you to get you out. I was trying to protect you.

question: From what? Why? Why did you give a shit about the building? Why did you care that we were there of all places?
answer: It's...it's a bad neighborhood. As you can see now.

question: Bullshit, Dad. Don't front me. For once. Just tell me the truth. I came from there, too.
answer: You were just a kid.

question: I saw your face. You knew that place. You knew those people.
answer: That's the past. It's dead.

question: You boys been hitting the pipe?
answer: No, Eddie. It's just that, I dunno. He was tall, and thin, and like a shadow, his face was just a blur. All I remember is the voice. It was smooth and low and it didn't seem to be comin' out of his mouth.

question: Then how'd you hear it, fool?
answer: It was just like in my head.

question: Maybe I oughta open a couple holes in that head and let all them voices out. You'll feel better, I promise.
answer: No, Eddie, man. Wait.

question: I told you not to lie to me. Now what the hell happened? Shutup, bitch. Now what, he just said to tell you what? He was back? Who was back?
answer: Bones.

question: He'll kill them. He'll kill every last one of them.
answer: Who?

question: Eddie Mack, that cop. And Jeremiah. And even when he's done, who knows. He won't be satisfied. Just like that demon dog. Feed it, and it just grows hungrier. Feed his hunger for revenge - he just wants more. Who knows where it'll stop. That kind of hunger ain't never satisfied.
answer: Aren't you gonna do something about it?

question: Like what? I got a little power, sure. A touch of the shining, a little of the sight. But no more than you do. We're not witches. I can't wiggle my nose or say a magic word and make him go away. Besides, maybe they deserve it. Maybe we all do.
answer: I don't. Patrick doesn't. And his brother and sister don't. And they're in the house with him.

question: Bones! Bones, you muthafuckah! What the hell you done to me?
answer: Not half what I'm planning on...

question: This some sick fucked up shit. What you want with my head?
answer: Just using it to carry your soul.

question: I don't understand it. You were my Man. Since we was grasshoppas. I always looked after you. You had a piece of everything I had.
answer: I didn't want a piece of yours, I wanted my own.

question: And the hell everybody else, right?
answer: Wait, Jimmy. Think about it. You woulda done the same thing if you was me.

question: Hey, baby.
answer: Jimmy, you've got --

question: I've got what I want. Turn around baby, look at me. Look at your man. I want you to do something for me, baby.
answer: What?

question: That's not Maurice --
answer: Maurice. Hold up, man. Okay, we're on the second floor. I feel it. No more steps. Bill?! Cinnabar? Cinnabar?!

question: I'm here.
answer: Bill! Bill?!

question: Patrick, he's...
answer: Okay, okay. Listen: Here, find my hand. The stairs are right near here. I saw them. Let's just walk up there.

question: I can't find you.
answer: Here!

question: Is that you?
answer: Yeah. Come on. Don't let go.

question: Please...help me...
answer: Dad?

question: Help me. I'm so sorry. But please, help me...
answer: Daddy?

question: Please. Help me. I'm scared. It hurts. I don't want to spend forever like this.
answer: No!!! Cinnabar! Stop! No! Cinnabar, no!!!!
